00022 
00023 /*--------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00024 /*                              MT/NT constants                             */
00025 /*  Four MT nibbles represent double, float, int, uchar (from most          */
00026 /*      significant to least significant).                                  */
00027 /*  Each "column" in the "table" below is essentially independant of the    */
00028 /*      other "columns", for example the CONVEXNATIVE entry means that the  */
00029 /*      floating point formats are in Convex native format but the integers */
00030 /*      are big-endian and standard sizes                                   */
00031 /*  If you add another value to this "table", you need to add another       */
00032 /*      DFNTF_xxx entry in hntdefs.h                                        */
00033 /*  The values for each nibble are:                                         */
00034 /*      1 - Big Endian                                                      */
00035 /*          (i.e. Big-Endian, 32-bit architecture w/IEEE Floats)            */
00036 /*      2 - VAX                                                             */
00037 /*          (i.e. Middle-Endian, 32-bit architecture w/VAX Floats)          */
00038 /*      3 - Cray                                                            */
00039 /*          (i.e. Big-Endian, all 64-bit architecture w/Cray Floats)        */
00040 /*      4 - Little Endian                                                   */
00041 /*          (i.e. Little-Endian, 32-bit architecture w/IEEE Floats)         */
00042 /*      5 - Convex                                                          */
00043 /*          (i.e. Big-Endian, 32-bit architecture w/Convex Native Floats)   */
00044 /*      6 - Fujitsu VP                                                      */
00045 /*          (i.e. Big-Endian, 32-bit architecture w/Fujitsu Native Floats)  */
00046 /*      7 - Cray MPP                                                        */
00047 /*          (i.e. Big-Endian, 32-bit architecture w/IEEE Floats, but no 16-bit type)            */
00048 /*      8 - Cray IEEE                                                       */
00049 /*          (i.e. Big-Endian, all 64-bit architecture w/IEEE Floats)        */
00050 /*--------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00051 #define     DFMT_SUN            0x1111 
00052 #define     DFMT_SUN_INTEL      0x4441
00053 #define     DFMT_ALLIANT        0x1111
00054 #define     DFMT_IRIX           0x1111
00055 #define     DFMT_APOLLO         0x1111
00056 #define     DFMT_IBM6000        0x1111
00057 #define     DFMT_HP9000         0x1111
00058 #define     DFMT_CONVEXNATIVE   0x5511
00059 #define     DFMT_CONVEX         0x1111
00060 #define     DFMT_UNICOS         0x3331
00061 #define     DFMT_UNICOSIEEE     0x1831
00062 #define     DFMT_CTSS           0x3331
00063 #define     DFMT_VAX            0x2221
00064 #define     DFMT_MIPSEL         0x4441
00065 #define     DFMT_PC             0x4441
00066 #define     DFMT_APPLE          0x1111
00067 #define     DFMT_APPLE_INTEL    0x4441
00068 #define     DFMT_MAC            0x1111
00069 #define     DFMT_SUN386         0x4441
00070 #define     DFMT_NEXT           0x1111
00071 #define     DFMT_MOTOROLA       0x1111
00072 #define     DFMT_ALPHA          0x4441
00073 #define     DFMT_VP             0x6611
00074 #define     DFMT_I860           0x4441
00075 #define     DFMT_CRAYMPP        0x1171
00076 #define     DFMT_IA64           0x4441
00077 #define     DFMT_LINUX64        0x4441
00078 #define     DFMT_POWERPC64      0x1111

00374 /*
00375  * BSD was originally defined with no value.  But some newer SGI system
00376  * header files (e.g., resolv.h) assume it has a value and evaluate it
00377  * in expressions, thus causing compiling errors.  This has been reported
00378  * to SGI as bug #781568.  SGI could not provide a list of the semantics
00379  * of BSD values and suggested a work around of setting BSD to 1.
00380  */
00381 #   define BSD 1

00544 /* CRAY XT3
00545  * Note from RedStorm helpdesk,
00546  * When I compile a C code with the '-v' option, it indicates that the compile
00547  * is done with the macros __QK_USER__ and __LIBCATAMOUNT__ defined.  In
00548  * addition, there are other macros like __x86_64__ defined as well, to
00549  * indicate processor type.  __QK_USER__ might be a good check for Catamount,
00550  * and __x86_64__ might be good for Opteron node.  You might try something
00551  * like the following in a header file:
00552  */
00553 #if ((defined(__QK_USER__)) && (defined(__x86_64__)))
00554 #define __CRAY_XT3__
00555 #endif

01396 /*-----------------------------------------------------*/
01397 /*              encode and decode macros               */
01398 /*-----------------------------------------------------*/
01399 
01400 #   define INT16ENCODE(p, i) \
01401 { *(p) = (uint8)(((uintn)(i) >> 8) & 0xff); (p)++; \
01402         *(p) = (uint8)((uintn)(i) & 0xff); (p)++; }
01403 
01404 #   define UINT16ENCODE(p, i) \
01405 { *(p) = (uint8)(((uintn)(i) >> 8) & 0xff); (p)++; *(p) = (uint8)((i) & 0xff); (p)++; }
01406 
01407 #   define INT32ENCODE(p, i) \
01408 { *(p) = (uint8)(((uint32)(i) >> 24) & 0xff); (p)++; \
01409         *(p) = (uint8)(((uint32)(i) >> 16) & 0xff); (p)++; \
01410         *(p) = (uint8)(((uint32)(i) >> 8) & 0xff); (p)++; \
01411         *(p) = (uint8)((uint32)(i) & 0xff); (p)++; }
01412 
01413 #   define UINT32ENCODE(p, i) \
01414 { *(p) = (uint8)(((i) >> 24) & 0xff); (p)++; \
01415         *(p) = (uint8)(((i) >> 16) & 0xff); (p)++; \
01416         *(p) = (uint8)(((i) >> 8) & 0xff); (p)++; \
01417         *(p) = (uint8)((i) & 0xff); (p)++; }
01418 
01419 #   define NBYTEENCODE(d, s, n) \
01420 {   HDmemcpy(d,s,n); p+=n }
01421 
01422 /* DECODE converts big endian bytes pointed by p to integer values and store
01423  * it in i.  For signed values, need to do sign-extension when converting
01424  * the 1st byte which carries the sign bit.
01425  * The macros does not require i be of a certain byte sizes.  It just requires
01426  * i be big enough to hold the intended value range.  E.g. INT16DECODE works
01427  * correctly even if i is actually a 64bit int like in a Cray.
01428  */
01429 
01430 #   define INT16DECODE(p, i) \
01431 { (i) = ((*(p) & 0x80) ? ~0xffff : 0x00) | ((int16)(*(p) & 0xff) << 8); (p)++; \
01432         (i) |= (int16)((*(p) & 0xff)); (p)++; }
01433 
01434 #   define UINT16DECODE(p, i) \
01435 { (i) = (uint16)((*(p) & 0xff) << 8); (p)++; \
01436         (i) |= (uint16)(*(p) & 0xff); (p)++; }
01437 
01438 #   define INT32DECODE(p, i) \
01439 { (i) = ((*(p) & 0x80) ? ~0xffffffff : 0x00) | ((int32)(*(p) & 0xff) << 24); (p)++; \
01440         (i) |= ((int32)(*(p) & 0xff) << 16); (p)++; \
01441         (i) |= ((int32)(*(p) & 0xff) << 8); (p)++; \
01442         (i) |= (*(p) & 0xff); (p)++; }
01443 
01444 #   define UINT32DECODE(p, i) \
01445 { (i) = ((uint32)(*(p) & 0xff) << 24); (p)++; \
01446         (i) |= ((uint32)(*(p) & 0xff) << 16); (p)++; \
01447         (i) |= ((uint32)(*(p) & 0xff) << 8); (p)++; \
01448         (i) |= (uint32)(*(p) & 0xff); (p)++; }
01449 
01450 /* Note! the NBYTEDECODE macro is backwards from the memcpy() routine, */
01451 /*      in the spirit of the other DECODE macros */
01452 #   define NBYTEDECODE(s, d, n) \
01453 {   HDmemcpy(d,s,n); p+=n }
01454 
01455 /*----------------------------------------------------------------
01456 ** MACRO FCALLKEYW for any special fortran-C stub keyword
01457 **
01458 ** MacIntosh MPW LS-fortran needs pascal since it can interface
01459 **  best with pascal functions.
01460 ** Microsoft C and Fortran need __fortran for Fortran callable C
01461 **  routines.
01462 **
01463 ** MACRO FRETVAL for any return value from a fortran-C stub function
01464 **  Replaces the older FCALLKEYW macro.
01465 **---------------------------------------------------------------*/
01466 #ifdef FRETVAL
01467 #undef FRETVAL
01468 #endif
01469 
01470 #if defined(MAC)                /* with LS FORTRAN */
01471 #ifndef ABSOFT
01472 #   define FCALLKEYW    pascal
01473 #   define FRETVAL(x)   pascal x
01474 #endif /* ABSOFT */
01475 #endif
01476 
01477 #ifndef FRETVAL /* !MAC */
01478 #   define FCALLKEYW    /*NONE*/
01479 #   define FRETVAL(x)   x
01480 #endif
01481 
01482 
01483 /*----------------------------------------------------------------
01484 ** MACRO FNAME for any fortran callable routine name.
01485 **
01486 **  This macro prepends, appends, or does not modify a name
01487 **  passed as a macro parameter to it based on the FNAME_PRE_UNDERSCORE,
01488 **  FNAME_POST_UNDERSCORE macros set for a specific system.
01489 **
01490 **---------------------------------------------------------------*/
01491 #if defined(FNAME_PRE_UNDERSCORE) && defined(FNAME_POST_UNDERSCORE)
01492 #   define FNAME(x)     _##x##_
01493 #endif
01494 #if defined(FNAME_PRE_UNDERSCORE) && !defined(FNAME_POST_UNDERSCORE)
01495 #   define FNAME(x)     _##x
01496 #endif
01497 #if !defined(FNAME_PRE_UNDERSCORE) && defined(FNAME_POST_UNDERSCORE)
01498 #   define FNAME(x)     x##_
01499 #endif
01500 #if !defined(FNAME_PRE_UNDERSCORE) && !defined(FNAME_POST_UNDERSCORE)
01501 #   define FNAME(x)     x
01502 #endif
